title: A fine wheel-cut flask Wheel-cut flask

  object_colour: pale blue

  physical_appearance: This flask is made of clear glass
 and is pale blue in colour. It has a short cut foot. The body of the flask is globular
 and is decorated with honeycomb indentations on its surface. The shoulder of the flask is stepped
 leading to a tapered cylindrical neck. The mouth of the flask has a broad rim
 with a hexagonal cut shape. It is slightly scratched on its surface.

  subject_terms_1: exports honeycomb (motif) glassware vessels

  subject_terms_2: Exports Motifs Bottles Islamic glassware

  subject_terms_3: Decorative arts

  sgcool_label_text: Made of clear glass in a pale blue tone
 this flask has a globular body and long tapering neck that opens up into a wide-rimmed hexagonal mouth. The decoration on the glass is created by a facet-cutting technique
 where the curved surface of the glass has been ground to produce flat or slightly concave areas. The resulting honeycomb pattern references earlier Sassanian bowls
 but the overall shape of the flask is regarded to be a distinctively Islamic form
 and hallmark of Iranian glass production from the 8th to the 12th century.

metadata.title_text: A fine wheel-cut flask Wheel-cut flask
metadata.physical_appearance: This flask is made of clear glass, and is pale blue in colour. It has a short cut foot. The body of the flask is globular, and is decorated with honeycomb indentations on its surface. The shoulder of the flask is stepped, leading to a tapered cylindrical neck. The mouth of the flask has a broad rim, with a hexagonal cut shape. It is slightly scratched on its surface.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Made of clear glass in a pale blue tone, this flask has a globular body and long tapering neck that opens up into a wide-rimmed hexagonal mouth. The decoration on the glass is created by a facet-cutting technique, where the curved surface of the glass has been ground to produce flat or slightly concave areas. The resulting honeycomb pattern references earlier Sassanian bowls, but the overall shape of the flask is regarded to be a distinctively Islamic form, and hallmark of Iranian glass production from the 8th to the 12th century.
